entry.title: Pelican: a static blog generator for Pythonistas
entry.summary:
Hi!

I would like to start this blog speaking about Pelican, a nice Python project that allows you to generate a complete blog/site from reStructuredText Templates.

Why would you do that? well, the point is that it generates a static site, that is, the resulting blog is a bunch of static files (HTML, CSS...), and this means it's incredibly easy to host. (In fact, you have several options for hosting it for free, even using your own domain).

Pelican comes with two predefined themes, but here you can find more themes. Is quite extensible and

reStructuredText

But, what a reStructuredText template looks like?

A blog entry would be as simple as the following text:

Title of a post
###############

Hi!

This is my first rst post!

And this is a link to my page_


.. _page: http://fjavieralba.com

reStructuredText is part of docutils, a powerful and open-source text processing system written in Python.

As you may know, it's mainly used for generating documentation. Sphinx is an awesome project that lets you generate your docmentation in multiple formats, writing it only once in rst.

Pelican

Pelican is an open source project initiated by Alexis Metaireau.

Installing Pelican

Pelican is pip-installable:

$ pip install pelican

If you're curious, you can review its code and clone the github repo.

Creating a site/blog

Once installed, all you have to do to create a brand new pelican site is type:

$ pelican .

This command will generate an output folder with an entire blog site with the default content. If you open the index.html file inside output you will see something similar to:

Writing a post

You will want to view more than the default content. To start writing posts, do the following:

  • create a directory with your site name:
$ mkdir my_blog
  • Inside that directory, create a directory where you will put your rst sources:
$ cd my_blog
$ mkdir rst
  • Create a rst file inside that directory with an example post:
$ vim my_first_post.rst
